comments:
I20050426-1700, GTK+ 2.6.4, KDE 3.3.2, Linux 2.6.11, X.org 6.8.2

It is possible to get Eclipse into a state where the editor tabs continue to
switch, in some kind of a loop.  It is possible to switch perspectives and open
menus when in this state; the editors will keep switching.

Typing in the console view will eventually cause it to stop.  (There is a slight
delay; be patient.)


STEPS TO REPRODUCE:
------------------
1.) Open four editors, and make sure Eclipse is big enough to show all the tabs.
2.) Select the right-most editor.
3.) Press "Ctrl+PageUp" three times really fast

Assume the editors were named A, B, C, D, and D was selected first.  Eclipse
will switch to editor C, B and then A.  At this point, Eclipse should stop. 
However, the cycle continues -- selecting this same group of editors in the same
order over again.

Try different combinations!  It's fun!

This appears to be caused by the fix for Bug 79123, though this might actually
represent a bug in traverse events on GTK+.  We are currently debugging other
traversal problems on GTK+.

Doug and I were unable to reproduce the problem on his machine or mine.  There 
must have been an additional step to get you into a bad state in the first 
place.

I am closing this as WORKSFORME but will keep an eye out for it.  Perhaps we 
can figure out the scenario to get into the bad state.

Please see Bug 93676.  While I can't provide more information, I think this is
important enough to warrant more investigation.  However, I think this bug
should be closed as a dupe of Bug 93676, as it contains more information.

I just reproduced this on windows. To reproduce, I had to have the Resource
Navigator open and link with editor on. (I also enabled single-click open and
"open when using arrow keys, although I'm not sure if that's relevant)
*** Bug 93676 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Removed my change to PartPane and problem still occurs.  In fact, I had the 
problem happen without even doing Ctrl+PageUp.  With the Navigator linked to 
the editor, it happened on startup for me.

Keeps flipping back and forth like that.

This was caused by a bug in the resource navigator. In handleSelectionChanged,
it schedules an asyncExec that updates the active editor. However, it does so
based on the selection at the time the asyncExec was scheduled, rather than the
current selection.

Since there is no protection against multiple *syncExecs being scheduled at
once, it can end up fighting itself for the active editor. This can be seen in
M5a: if you follow the same steps, you can see the selection change back and
forth several times before it settles on an active editor. However, in M5 things
settled down after 2 cycles because the workbench page was not notifying its
listeners of activation changes triggered by bringToTop. Now that the listeners
are being notified, the cycle has become infinite.

Fixed in head. The resource navigator now will only schedule one *syncExec at a
time, and it will always get the most recent selection from the widget when it does.

Careful.

    /**
     * Brings the corresponding editor to top if the selected resource is open.
     * 
     * @since 2.0
     */
    protected void linkToEditor(IStructuredSelection selection) {

was just changed into:

    /**
     * Brings the corresponding editor to top if the selected resource is open.
     * 
     * @since 2.0
     */
    protected void linkToEditor() {

The context is a public non-final class, in an API package, and there is no 
explicit indication in spec that a client is not allowed to subclass. That 
makes all public and protected methods API methods. Changing the signature 
would be a breaking API change.
Ouch. Didn't know I was in an API package. Thanks, Jim. Fixed again.
